Award.AwardTitle: CSR: Medium: Collaborative Research: Facets: Exploring Semantic Equivalence of Files to Improve Storage Systems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit:
The focus of the proposal is on finding semantically equivalent files in an efficient and scalable manner. If two files are identical, they are candidates for optimizations to reduce storage costs, increase performance, and generally improve the system. Traditionally, two files are only considered equivalent if they are byte-by-byte identical - i.e., byte equivalence. However, this team's preliminary research shows that there are many other files that are essentially equivalent, even though the bytes they contain are not the same. This proposal will investigate how to find such cases and perform optimizations that make use of semantic equivalence, rather than byte equivalence.

This project will design and implement a framework, Facets, which explores new capabilities by applying optimizations to files that are essentially transformed versions of each other. Many optimizations and improvements can be applied to semantically equivalent files, including:

-Ensuring that the security of semantically equivalent files is preserved
-Easing backup and maintenance of semantically equivalent files in various formats, fidelities, and versions
-Using semantically equivalent files to improve performance, reliability, and availability
-Regenerating semantically equivalent files to speed up recovery and network transfer
-Selecting which semantically equivalent files to access according to performance or energy constraints

This team's preliminary research shows that 5% of files on a typical user's machine are original content. The rest are copies of files from elsewhere or various derivatives of original content. While leveraging this observation to achieve advantages is not trivial, many significant improvements are possible if one can find these relationships and make proper use of them. These improvements include enhanced security, more efficient backup and restoration, better file caching, more intelligent tradeoffs in performance versus power use, and a host of other possibilities.

Broader Impacts:
The code and techniques developed will be released in open source form. The team will take steps (such as applying for supplemental REU grants) to involve undergraduates in the research. They will give talks and recruit at Hispanic-serving institutions. Materials and concepts from the research will be incorporated into classes taught by the principal investigators at their institutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
For traditional systems, the notion of equivalence occurs when two data items are bit-by-bit identical.  This research seeks to relax this notion of equivalence and explore newly enabled capabilities.  


One area of this research involves exploiting semantically equivalent representations of data for security purposes.  For example, a social security number can be represented, displayed, and entered as an alias (e.g., $ssn) on a smartphone screen when being accessed in public. While the concept seems simple, the research involves conducting human-subject surveys to identify the need for this capability and designing and building a system named Cashtags that is one of the first prototypes addressing this problem.  Some major challenges include (1) ensuring this capability is backward compatible with existing features such as auto completion, (2) handling variants of information formats (e.g., phone numbers with and without area code), and (3) fitting our new component into the existing system with minimal changes.  The techniques developed are patent pending, and results have been published at the USENIX Security Conference.  


The notion of semantic equivalence can also be applied in other areas.  As many data files are frequently accessed together, they can be physically represented as a single file, which is semantically equivalent to representing them as individual files.  In doing so, we can speed up the performance of storage by up to 27%.  Furthermore, semantically equivalent content can be managed with the same security policy (e.g., secure deletion).  These results have been published at the USENIX Conference on File and Storage Technologies and ACM Transactions on Storage.


In terms of education, this research has supported 1 postdoc, 4 graduate research assistants, and 2 undergraduate research assistants.  Three of these are from underrepresented groups.  The research infrastructures developed and the research data and traces gathered have enabled 43 graduate students and 2 undergraduate students to contribute to this project through graduate-level course projects and independent research.  This grant enabled the completion of two Ph.D.s.  One is now an assistant professor at the University of Northern Iowa; the other recently joined T-Mobile.
